G.L. c. 218, \u00a7\u00a7 19, 19A..proposition: The amount in controversy exceeds the minimum jurisdictional amount of this Court, as Plaintiff has incurred medical expenses of approximately $12,000, lost wages of approximately $2,500, and other damages, all of which are reasonably expected to exceed $7,000, exclusive of interest and costs.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 2.proposition: Venue is proper in Lynn District Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, § 2 because the events and omissions giving rise to this claim occurred in Lynn, Essex County, Massachusetts, and the Premises are located in this judicial district.

G.L. c. 143, \u00a7 3T.proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant, as landlord, had a non-delegable duty to maintain the common-area smoke detector in working order in compliance with applicable law, including without limitation G.L. c. 143, § 3T; G.L. c. 148, §§ 26F, 26F½; and the Massachusetts State Fire Code (527 CMR).

G.L. c. 148, \u00a7\u00a7 26F, 26F\u00bd.proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant, as landlord, had a non-delegable duty to maintain the common-area smoke detector in working order in compliance with applicable law, including without limitation G.L. c. 143, § 3T; G.L. c. 148, §§ 26F, 26F½; and the Massachusetts State Fire Code (527 CMR).

Massachusetts State Fire Code (527 CMR).proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant, as landlord, had a non-delegable duty to maintain the common-area smoke detector in working order in compliance with applicable law, including without limitation G.L. c. 143, § 3T; G.L. c. 148, §§ 26F, 26F½; and the Massachusetts State Fire Code (527 CMR).

Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a landlord owes a duty of reasonable care to tenants and lawful occupants in the maintenance of common areas under the landlord’s control.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).support_reasoning: Mounsey v. Ellard abolishes the common-law invitee/licensee distinction in Massachusetts and adopts a unified reasonable-care standard for occupiers of land toward all lawful visitors. That principle necessarily encompasses landlords as occupiers and tenants and their lawful occupants as lawful visitors in common areas under the landlord’s control. Although the excerpt provided is from a concurrence and focuses on trespassers, the majority opinion in Mounsey clearly establishes a general duty of reasonable care to all lawful entrants, supporting the stated proposition.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).relevant_excerpt: We hold, therefore, that the common law distinctions between licensees and invitees are abolished in this Commonwealth. Henceforth, the duty owed by an occupier of land to all lawful visitors will be the duty to act as a reasonable man in all the circumstances. Factors to be considered in determining the scope of this duty include the foreseeability of harm, the magnitude of the risk of harm, and the burden of avoiding the harm.

Poole v. Lynn Housing Auth., 107 Mass. A.raw_text: Poole v. Lynn Housing Auth., 107 Mass. App. Ct. 563 (2024)
Poole v. Lynn Housing Auth., 107 Mass. A.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a landlord owes a duty of reasonable care to tenants and lawful occupants in the maintenance of common areas under the landlord’s control.

Young v. Garwacki, 380 Mass. 162 (1980).proposition: Defendant owed Plaintiff a duty to exercise reasonable care to keep the common hallways in a reasonably safe condition and to maintain safety devices therein, including smoke detectors, in compliance with applicable statutes, regulations, and building and fire codes.
Young v. Garwacki, 380 Mass. 162 (1980).support_reasoning: Young v. Garwacki holds that a landlord owes a duty of reasonable care in negligence for defective *rented* premises (here, a second‑floor porch) and discusses statutes imposing duties after notice of unsafe conditions. The case mentions building and sanitary codes only in the context of warranty of habitability and G.L. c. 186, § 19, but it does not specifically address common hallways or an affirmative duty to maintain safety devices such as smoke detectors in compliance with codes. Thus it supports a general landlord duty of reasonable care, not the specific proposition about common hallways and smoke detectors/code compliance.
Young v. Garwacki, 380 Mass. 162 (1980).relevant_excerpt: “In the landlord-tenant field, we have held that a landlord is liable to a tenant’s guest for failing to exercise due care in maintaining common passageways under the landlord’s control without regard to their condition at the time of the letting. Lindsey v. Massios, supra. We said that ‘the status of the person visited, landowner or lessee, should not affect the visitor’s right to personal safety or the landowner’s obligation reasonably to maintain premises in his control.’ … Thus, at least to the extent required by the relevant housing and building codes, a landlord may be liable to his tenant for failing to maintain areas not under the landlord’s control.”

State Building Code (780 CMR).proposition: The provisions of the State Building Code (780 CMR) and State Fire Code (527 CMR), together with G.L. c. 143 and G.L. c. 148, are designed, among other things, to protect the health and safety of occupants from fire-related injury, and Plaintiff is a member of the class of persons intended to be protected by these statutes and regulations.

Perry v. Medeiros, 369 Mass. 836 (1976).proposition: The provisions of the State Building Code (780 CMR) and State Fire Code (527 CMR), together with G.L. c. 143 and G.L. c. 148, are designed, among other things, to protect the health and safety of occupants from fire-related injury, and Plaintiff is a member of the class of persons intended to be protected by these statutes and regulations.
Perry v. Medeiros, 369 Mass. 836 (1976).support_reasoning: The opinion does recognize a building code provision as a safety regulation whose violation is evidence of negligence, but it concerns a municipal building code, not the State Building Code (780 CMR), State Fire Code (527 CMR), G.L. c. 143, or G.L. c. 148. The court does not interpret or discuss those state statutes or regulations, nor does it explicitly analyze the class of persons intended to be protected by them. Thus, while generally consistent with the idea that safety codes protect against falls, Perry v. Medeiros does not provide direct authority for the specific proposition about 780 CMR, 527 CMR, c. 143, and c. 148 or the protected class under those provisions.
Perry v. Medeiros, 369 Mass. 836 (1976).relevant_excerpt:
“The provision of the Taunton building code which the judge excluded was clearly intended to eliminate or minimize the risk of falls, with resulting injuries, in passing through a doorway which opens directly to the top step of a set of stairs going down from the other side of the door.”

“‘The general rule in Massachusetts is that violation of the safety statute or ordinance does not in itself give rise to a cause of action but is evidence of negligence.’”

Cott v. Environics Corp., 57 Mass. App..raw_text: Cott v. Environics Corp., 57 Mass. App. Ct. 684 (2003)
Cott v. Environics Corp., 57 Mass. App..proposition: Having undertaken to provide smoke detection in the common hallway, Defendant had a duty to exercise reasonable care in maintaining that smoke detector in operable condition and to act reasonably upon receiving notice that it was not functioning.
Cott v. Environics Corp., 57 Mass. App..support_reasoning: The opinion provided is not Cott v. Environics Corp. at all, but a criminal case involving Article 36 of the Vienna Convention (Diemer). It deals with consular notification rights, suppression of evidence, prior consistent statements, prior bad acts, and jury instructions, and says nothing about premises liability, smoke detectors, or a defendant’s duty to maintain hallway smoke detection equipment. Therefore it does not support the stated proposition about a duty to maintain a smoke detector after undertaking to provide it.
Cott v. Environics Corp., 57 Mass. App..relevant_excerpt: Not applicable. The opinion text concerns Vienna Convention consular notification rights and related evidentiary issues, and contains no discussion of smoke detectors, common hallways, or duties arising from undertaking to provide fire safety devices.

Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148 (201.proposition: Defendant’s failure to act in the face of known code and safety violations constitutes a breach of its duty of reasonable care.
Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148 (201.support_reasoning: The case is about a landowner’s premises-liability duty concerning an open and obvious hazard created and maintained by the defendants, not about failure to act in the face of known ‘code and safety violations.’ The court’s analysis turns on Restatement § 343A and the duty to remedy a dangerous condition the landowner created and knew would be encountered, not on violations of statutes, regulations, or building codes or a failure to correct such violations. Thus it supports a broader duty-of-care/remedy principle, but not the specific code-violation proposition stated.
Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148 (201.relevant_excerpt: “While the open and obvious doctrine may relieve the defendant of its duty to warn, the doctrine does not mean that the defendant can maintain its property ‘in an unreasonably unsafe condition as long as the unsafe condition is open and obvious.’ … Here, Jose set up a trampoline immediately adjacent to a two-foot-deep pool…for the very purpose of enabling people to jump from the trampoline into the pool. … In many ways, Jose’s actions were equivalent to installing a diving board in the shallow end of an in-ground pool.”

Lindsey v. Massios, 372 Mass. 79 (1977).proposition: Defendant’s failure to act in the face of known code and safety violations constitutes a breach of its duty of reasonable care.
Lindsey v. Massios, 372 Mass. 79 (1977).support_reasoning: The court squarely holds that a landlord owes lawful visitors, including tenants’ guests, a duty of reasonable care in maintaining common areas and that violations of safety statutes (here, a lighting requirement) are evidence of negligence. The opinion explains that failure to maintain required lighting in common passageways, in violation of G.L. c. 144, § 61, may be found by the jury to constitute a breach of this duty. Thus, the case directly supports the proposition that a defendant’s failure to act in the face of known code and safety violations can constitute a breach of reasonable care.
Lindsey v. Massios, 372 Mass. 79 (1977).relevant_excerpt: “Therefore, we no longer follow the common law rule that a landlord owes to his tenants’ visitors the same duty he owes to his tenants concerning the maintenance of common passageways in his control… The landowner’s duty of reasonable care in maintaining property he controls extends to all lawful visitors on his premises, including the lawful visitors of his tenants… If Massios violated a statutory duty concerning safe maintenance of common passageways within her control, such a violation is evidence of negligence which the jury may consider.”

Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.raw_text: Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc., 408 Mass. 355 (1990)
Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.proposition: Defendant’s violation of building and fire safety statutes and regulations, including but not limited to G.L. c. 143, § 3T; G.L. c. 148, §§ 26F, 26F½; and applicable provisions of 527 CMR and 780 CMR regarding the installation and maintenance of smoke detectors, is evidence of negligence.
Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.case_name: Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc.
Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely addresses the effect of violating a safety statute (here, G.L. c. 138, § 69) on civil negligence liability. The SJC reiterates the Massachusetts rule that statutory violations do not constitute negligence per se but are “some evidence” of negligence as to the harms the statute was designed to prevent. Although the case involves liquor-control, not building/fire codes, the doctrinal point is general and applies equally to building and fire safety statutes and regulations: their violation is evidence of negligence, not automatic liability.
Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.relevant_excerpt: “It has long been the rule in this Commonwealth that violation of a statute does not by itself establish a breach of duty, for it does not constitute negligence per se. LaClair v. Silberline Mfg. Co., 379 Mass. 21, 28 (1979), and cases cited. Rather, violation of a statute such as § 69 is only ‘some evidence’ of the defendant's negligence as to all consequences the statute was intended to prevent. Cimino v. Milford Keg, Inc., supra. Adamian v. Three Sons, Inc., 353 Mass. 498, 499 (1968).”

527 CMR.proposition: Defendant’s violation of building and fire safety statutes and regulations, including but not limited to G.L. c. 143, § 3T; G.L. c. 148, §§ 26F, 26F½; and applicable provisions of 527 CMR and 780 CMR regarding the installation and maintenance of smoke detectors, is evidence of negligence.

780 CMR.proposition: Defendant’s violation of building and fire safety statutes and regulations, including but not limited to G.L. c. 143, § 3T; G.L. c. 148, §§ 26F, 26F½; and applicable provisions of 527 CMR and 780 CMR regarding the installation and maintenance of smoke detectors, is evidence of negligence.

Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141 (2006).proposition: Defendant’s negligence created a foreseeable and unreasonable risk that building occupants, including Plaintiff, would be harmed by fire or smoke without adequate warning. The very purpose of smoke detectors is to provide early notice to prevent such injuries, and the harm Plaintiff suffered is the kind of harm that proper maintenance of smoke detectors is intended to prevent.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141 (2006).support_reasoning: The case concerns negligent storage of firearms and the foreseeability of criminal misuse of a stolen gun, not negligent failure to provide or maintain smoke detectors, fire alarms, or warning systems. Its duty and foreseeability analysis are tied specifically to firearms as dangerous instrumentalities and the risk of third-party criminal violence, not fire- or smoke-related harm or the protective purpose of smoke detectors. Thus it does not provide authority for a proposition about negligence creating a foreseeable risk of harm from fire or smoke without adequate warning devices.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “In the circumstances of this case, we conclude that a homeowner who permits guns to be stored on her property and allows unsupervised access to that property by a person known by her to have a history of violence and mental instability, has a duty of reasonable care to ensure that the guns are properly secured. This duty is owed to, inter alia, a law enforcement officer shot by the person granted unsupervised access, because the officer is a foreseeable victim of the alleged improper firearm storage.”

Jesionek v. Mass. Port Auth., 376 Mass..raw_text: Jesionek v. Mass. Port Auth., 376 Mass. 101 (1978)
Jesionek v. Mass. Port Auth., 376 Mass..proposition: There were no intervening or superseding causes sufficient to break the chain of causation between Defendant’s negligence and Plaintiff’s injuries; rather, the kitchen fire combined with Defendant’s failure to maintain smoke detection to cause Plaintiff’s harm.
Jesionek v. Mass. Port Auth., 376 Mass..support_reasoning: The case concerns proximate cause and whether an intervening third party’s wrongful conduct (an intoxicated seaman operating an unsecured forklift) breaks the chain of causation from the defendant’s negligence. It does not involve fires, smoke detection, or any analogous fact pattern, and the court’s discussion of foreseeability and intervening acts is tied specifically to negligent failure to secure a forklift, not to fire-safety or smoke-alarm maintenance. Thus it cannot properly be cited for a proposition about a kitchen fire combining with failure to maintain smoke detection without an intervening/superseding cause breaking causation.
Jesionek v. Mass. Port Auth., 376 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “The general rule is that ‘[t]he act of a third person, intervening and contributing a condition necessary to the injurious effect of the original negligence, will not excuse the first wrongdoer, if such act ought to have been foreseen. The original negligence still remains a culpable and direct cause of the injury.’… Under the facts of this case the jury would have been warranted in concluding that the actions of the seaman were foreseeable… Consequently, a jury could have found that the plaintiff’s injury was caused by a negligent act for which the authority was responsible.”

Guiliana v. Globe Bakery, Inc., 334 Mass.raw_text: Guiliana v. Globe Bakery, Inc., 334 Mass. 81 (1956)
Guiliana v. Globe Bakery, Inc., 334 Mass.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, Plaintiff is entitled to recover fair and reasonable compensation for all past and future damages proximately caused by Defendant’s negligence.
Guiliana v. Globe Bakery, Inc., 334 Mass.case_name: Zarum v. Brass Mill Materials Corp.
Guiliana v. Globe Bakery, Inc., 334 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion is a contract/unjust enrichment dispute over entitlement to a corporate tax refund and does not involve a negligence claim, tort damages, or any discussion of the measure of personal injury damages. It therefore does not address, much less establish, the principle that a plaintiff in a Massachusetts negligence action is entitled to fair and reasonable compensation for all past and future damages proximately caused by the defendant’s negligence. The case is inapposite to the stated proposition.
Guiliana v. Globe Bakery, Inc., 334 Mass.relevant_excerpt: The plaintiff brings this action of contract to recover one half of a tax refund received by the defendant corporation from the United States. … The contract entered into by the parties is comprehensive and appears to have been carefully drawn; it specifically covered the subject matter of tax refunds and the parties have set out the only conditions under which the plaintiff would be entitled to recover if the corporation received a refund. In these circumstances there is no room for an implied contract; nor is there any basis for recovery on principles of unjust enrichment.

Corsetti v. Stone Co., 396 Mass. 1 (1985.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, Plaintiff is entitled to recover fair and reasonable compensation for all past and future damages proximately caused by Defendant’s negligence.
Corsetti v. Stone Co., 396 Mass. 1 (1985.support_reasoning: The provided text is from a dissent focused on the collateral source rule and evidentiary discretion, not on the general standard for measuring tort damages. It does not discuss or state that a plaintiff is entitled to recover all fair and reasonable past and future damages proximately caused by the defendant’s negligence. Thus, this opinion segment does not provide authority for the claimed damages proposition.
Corsetti v. Stone Co., 396 Mass. 1 (1985.relevant_excerpt: Collateral source evidence has been deemed irrelevant because “the receipts from the outside source do not go to reduce the defendant’s liability; yet jurors might be led by the irrelevancy to consider plaintiffs’ claims unimportant or trivial or to refuse plaintiffs’ verdicts or reduce them, believing that otherwise there would be unjust double recovery.” Goldstein v. Gontarz, 364 Mass. 800, 809 (1974).

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Award Plaintiff pre-judgment and post-judgment interest as allowed by law, including pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 6B;

G.L. c. 261.proposition: Award Plaintiff her taxable costs of this action under G.L. c. 261 and applicable rules;

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 60.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 60 and the Massachusetts Rules of Civil Procedure, Plaintiff demands a trial by jury on all issues so triable.
